7.text: On the extensive grasslands of The Plains of Venezuela,

10.text: small patches of jungle provide oases for the local fauna.

27.text: These jungles are mere specks on the vast open plains, but during the dry season,

33.text: when the heat turns the grasslands into an inferno, they are the only the shade,

37.text: the only refuge for many of the animals of this forgotten corner of the world.

57.text: In the shelter of the forest, the animals find food and protection.

61.text: While out on the plains the abundance which follows the rains is soon replaced by the scarcity of the long dry season,

68.text: here, among the trees, it is always possible to find food, in the form of fruits, leaves and seeds.

84.text: And with so many vegetarians around, hunters, naturally, are also drawn here.

90.text: The "matas", as these small Venezuelan forests are called, also contain dangers.

97.text: The shadows of the enormous trees provide relief from the burning sun,

103.text: but may also at times conceal death.

112.text: Our story begins here, in the heart of the forest.

115.text: In the shade of the impressive ceibas and mangos our heroine, a morrocoy tortoise,

122.text: is enjoying the abundance and the cool of the mata,

125.text: little suspecting her luck is about to change.

136.text: Though it is a species in danger of extinction, the morrocoys are a sought-after delicacy on the plains.

143.text: From time to time, people enter the forest in search of a change from their usual diet of rice and beans,

149.text: and the tortoises are both tasty and easy to catch.

159.text: Unaware that her life hangs by a thread, our heroine now begins an extraordinary journey.

165.text: The plains-dwellers cook them in their shells as soon as they get back to the village.

170.text: But luck is on her side.

173.text: In her white prison, in a world she is incapable of understanding,

178.text: the morrocoy tortoise does not know she is about to discover the different worlds of the Plains of Venezuela.

184.text: It will be a long, dangerous journey to get back home.

189.text: This is her story, the adventure of a voyage in search of paradise in hell.

206.text: During the hot months night comes as a great relief out on the open plains.

211.text: For the plains dwellers, this is the time to sit around the fire and exchange their experiences of the day.

218.text: Alcohol is passed round, relaxing both mind and body, and making them less alert.

223.text: For the captured tortoise, their relaxed mood offers a chance to make a dash for freedom.

230.text: With slow steps, she leaves behind certain death and escapes into the night.

237.text: But her odyssey has just begun.

240.text: Because far away from the forest, the plains are a constant survival test.

255.text: At dawn, life, until then hidden, again stirs on the vast open expanses.

262.text: Three hundred thousand square kilometres of apparently deserted horizons fill with living shadows.

269.text: The animals take advantage of the hours before the heat sets in to eat and gather together.

275.text: The entire plain comes to life with the constant movement of thousands of living beings.

286.text: The capybaras scare great flocks of red-billed whistling ducks,

290.text: whose wing beats sound out over the swamps every day at dawn.

293.text: They are just one part of the incredible community of birds on the plains,

299.text: where there are more different species than in the United States and England put together.

321.text: The forest also comes to life at dawn,

323.text: and it does so with the cries of the howler monkeys.

330.text: This noisy communication between groups, marking out their territories,

334.text: shows that no predator can reach them up in the treetops.

337.text: But down below, on the ground, things are very different.

341.text: The peccaries are permanently on the alert.

345.text: They also take advantage of the cool hours around dawn to make short trips beyond the limits of the forest.

351.text: It is a less frequented area, so it is easier to find fruits which have fallen from nearby trees;

358.text: a trophy which is often the cause of disputes.

375.text: Beyond, stretches the sea of grass, a world open to the sun,

378.text: the natural habitat of animals adapted to these conditions, but an unknown world for a tortoise

384.text: who has spent her entire life in the shade of the jungle.

391.text: the morrocoy tortoise sets out across the landscape of parched grasses,

395.text: unaware that attentive, yellow eyes are closely observing her.

403.text: A burrowing owl sees her approach his nest, and is not prepared to tolerate intruders.

408.text: Under the ground, in a pleasant, cool tunnel, his chick is hidden,

415.text: and the owl plucks up his courage and tries to scare off the armoured stranger.

429.text: The tortoise does not know what is happening.

432.text: No bird in the forest in which she lived had ever attacked her.

435.text: There, they all know that the morrocoys are inoffensive.

439.text: But this is the open plain, and here any animal is a potential enemy.

453.text: Confused, the tortoise changes his course, away from the little owl's nest.

458.text: This has been her first contact with this new, harsh and hostile world to which she does not belong,

465.text: a world she will have to cross if she wants to again reach the safety of the forest.

472.text: As the tortoise scuttles off, life again returns to normal for the owl family.

478.text: Once the danger has passed, the female emerges from the hole,

483.text: accompanied by the only surviving chick from the eleven eggs she had laid,

487.text: while the male flies off in search of nearby prey.

492.text: The burrowing owls eat almost any animal which is not bigger than them.

496.text: If you hope to survive in this harsh environment you can't afford to be a choosy eater,

501.text: and these small birds of prey happily devour anything from insects and amphibians to squirrels and lizards.

514.text: On this occasion it is a mouse that has fallen into his claws.

518.text: The male breaks its neck with his beak, and then carries it back to the hole,

524.text: where the female tears it apart and prepares it.

527.text: But the chick, which has already developed feathers, becomes impatient,

531.text: and decides to take the largest part of the booty into the safety of the nest to devour it in peace.

538.text: The burrowing owls rarely dig their own holes.

541.text: Generally, they use the tunnels made by another inhabitant of these wide plains,

546.text: an ancient animal which in the early morning retires underground.

563.text: The nine-band armadillo is one of the descendents of a race of armour-plated creatures

568.text: that have lived on earth for millions of years, with virtually no physiological changes.

578.text: The armour from which their name comes protects them against enemies

582.text: and allows them to make their way through the undergrowth.

585.text: But it presents a distinct disadvantage during the hot hours on the plains.

593.text: The leathery surface of its dark scales rapidly absorbs heat.

597.text: When the sun comes out and temperatures rise, the armadillo's protective shields cause it to overheat,

604.text: and it has to seek cover underground.

606.text: And this curious survivor of former ages not only does this rapidly and efficiently,

612.text: but what's more, digs its burrows at the base of the termite mounds that are scattered across the plains,

628.text: These structures offer the armadillo two great advantages.

632.text: On the one hand, they have a sophisticated ventilation system

635.text: and, on the other hand, they are full of termites.

638.text: The lodger thus has an air-conditioned room and a larder full of food.

653.text: For our tortoise, the sun becomes increasingly unbearable.

657.text: Its reptile physiology will help it to bear the heat,

661.text: but she is disorientated in this dry, suffocating world.

665.text: Finally, a breeze carries across the smell of water, and indicates which way she should proceed.

672.text: And slowly, patiently she enters the lowlands where the water

677.text: left behind after the rains still feeds the last patches of green on the plain.

687.text: Swamps and low-lying areas still hold water until well into the dry season.

699.text: The soil of the plains is thick clay,

702.text: and this is the essential factor making such incredible biodiversity possible

705.text: in a place where conditions are so harsh.

708.text: Because the clay prevents the water from draining away, and so pools form.

713.text: For the animals of the plains, the flooded areas provide relief from the intense heat.

718.text: While the burning sun paralyses life on the grasslands,

722.text: the fauna of the plains gathers here in search of food and water.

736.text: During the day, thousands of birds come here to feed.

747.text: Under the shallow waters of the flood areas swim innumerable fish.

750.text: As the dry season advances, the patches of water become increasingly smaller

756.text: and the fish progressively concentrate, making them easier to catch.

760.text: And so, the pool is crowded with fishers.

773.text: The American ibises search the cloudy waters for small fish.

778.text: They move their extraordinarily specialised beaks from side to side until they find their prey,

784.text: fish of between three and five centimetres in length.

787.text: If they touch weeds, branches or fish of different sizes they calmly continue their search.

793.text: But if the beak brushes up against one of the fish they are looking for,

798.text: it will clamp shut with amazing speed,

800.text: trapping the victim in twenty-five thousandths of a second

803.text: one of the fastest reactions of any vertebrate in the world.

815.text: Scarlet ibises, spoonbills, ducks and egrets, American ibises

821.text: each one uses a different technique,

823.text: hunts different prey and has a different shaped tool, the beak.

827.text: It is a mass gathering of specialists with jaws adapted to a specific type of prey,

833.text: and so reducing competition among species.

846.text: From up in the air, too, there is a beak that can skim the water in search of fish close to the surface,

851.text: and that beak belongs to the scissorbill.

870.text: Like the ibises, the scissorbills are selective and only close their beaks

876.text: if they touch a fish of the right size.

877.text: Even so, it is a risky fishing technique because on occasions

881.text: the obstacles they come across turn out to be spectacled caimans.

901.text: The water masses of the Orinoco basin are often covered in a blanket of bright green.

907.text: Millions of water hyacinths colonise the pools, forming small floating forests.

920.text: Below the water, the hyacinths form an intricate network, a tangled aquatic maze.

925.text: Floating on the swollen shoot of its base leaves, the hyacinths spread out their roots

931.text: until they join with those of neighbouring plants,

934.text: to such an extent that they completely cover the surface of the pools,

937.text: preventing sunlight from penetrating into the water, or gases being exchanged.

943.text: This could be fatal for the aquatic fauna and flora.

947.text: But the plains also have a powerful army of hyacinth-eaters,

951.text: which clear the surface of the water as they incessantly graze.

969.text: Thousands of capybaras daily feed on the succulent leaves of the aquatic plants.

974.text: These powerful rodents, the largest in the world,

977.text: live an amphibious life between the warm clear banks

980.text: and this enormous vegetable soup where they find food,

983.text: protection and relief from the implacable sun.

992.text: To be able to dominate this aquatic world,

994.text: the capybaras have acquired important physiological adaptations over millions of years of evolution.

999.text: These are their weapons with which to conquer the water:

1003.text: paws with webbed fingers to swim and dive, and eyes, ears and nostrils placed at the top of the head,

1010.text: so they can receive all the information from the surface when they are submerged.

1027.text: A great part of their success in colonising the plains is due to their social behaviour.

1032.text: The capybaras are very gregarious animals.

1035.text: The groups are normally composed of thirty individuals,

1039.text: but can be of up to one hundred, so social links, which begin with the family from the moment they are born,

1044.text: are vitally important, and must be constantly reinforced.

1059.text: When it is time to reproduce, the capybaras go into the water.

1063.text: On land they are more vulnerable so, when they are going to mate,

1066.text: the male follows the female into a shallow pool

1069.text: and, beneath the protection of the water, they copulate.

1094.text: The heat, which becomes increasingly intense as the morning advances,

1098.text: brings new dangers to the water.

1111.text: An anaconda approaches the capybaras' pool.

1115.text: It is an adult, over four metres in length,

1118.text: and its life is now not as aquatic as it was during the early stages, when it fed on frogs and small fish.

1124.text: But when the heat becomes unbearable out on the plain,

1128.text: it returns to its former hunting grounds.

1131.text: It knows it is now strong enough to catch larger prey,

1135.text: and silently moves its powerful rings until it is submerged in the water.

1146.text: The group of capybaras senses the danger.

1149.text: The adults, who have seen the reptile arrive, keep a careful watch on it.

1153.text: Only the head of the anaconda is above the water,

1156.text: as it hopes to go unnoticed until one of the young comes close to its jaws.

1161.text: But this time, it has been discovered.

1167.text: The experienced parents raise the alarm, and the group swims off beneath the hyacinths.

1173.text: Without the surprise factor, the giant anaconda will have no chance of catching them.

1181.text: Meanwhile, on the banks, a group of turtles has silently witnessed this scene, the anaconda's frustration.

1187.text: And now, they watch on as an exhausted morrocoy tortoise arrives.

1192.text: Our heroine has reached the water, guided by the smell.

1196.text: Here, along the bank, she finally sees animals she recognises.

1201.text: Turtles sometimes go into the forest to lay their eggs,

1205.text: and the tortoise has seen them before, close to her home.

1209.text: But now, she is the intruder.

1212.text: Though they are very close relatives, in the water the turtles have a great advantage.

1227.text: She hesitates, raises her head, not daring to advance.

1231.text: In the distance, she can see the treetops of her beloved jungle.

1235.text: But in between lies a daunting challenge.

1250.text: The width of the pool is almost an ocean for the little morrocoy,

1254.text: and she can't swim as well as her cousins the turtles.

1257.text: She has never crossed a pool.

1260.text: In truth, in the jungle where she was born she has never had to swim at all,

1265.text: so, very unwillingly, she decides to turn back and try to reach the jungle by going around the pool.

1271.text: And now, out on the plain, the day is really heating up.

1290.text: During the midday hours the beats down mercilessly on the plains.

1299.text: A scorched atmosphere robs the ground of humidity, dehydrating everything,

1306.text: It is a time of immobility, of extreme stillness.

1310.text: The entire plain appears to crystallise.

1317.text: While the animals near the pools spend hours submerged and immobile,

1321.text: on the plains of the interior the scarce shadows become much sought-after shelters.

1334.text: The dry season advances, and for the weakest the heat proves too much.

1340.text: For many, like this cow, the rainy season will never come.

1358.text: This time of death is a period of abundance for the scavengers and opportunists of the plain.

1367.text: Animals which are sick or have some physical deficiency

1371.text: die during these days of suffocating heat.

1374.text: The dead capybaras attract the turkey vultures and black vultures,

1378.text: the scavenger birds of the plains, who fight the spectacled caimans for the bodies.

1383.text: The caimans' normal diet is fish, so they take advantage of any occasion to eat a capybara,

1390.text: or at least the skin left behind by the voracious scavengers.

1408.text: In a world of such open landscapes, an animal has hardly died

1412.text: before a entire horde of black undertakers arrives.

1423.text: They are not exactly the most appealing of animals,

1425.text: but they play a vital role in sustaining the ecosystem.

1429.text: The relentless heat, and the many dead bodies could cause epidemics and diseases

1434.text: if these death-loving scavengers did not act swiftly and efficiently.

1451.text: The water levels of the pools continue to fall, and the surface of the plains dries out.

1457.text: The smaller lagoons become small marshy pools where fish concentrate,

1461.text: fighting for the last mouthfuls of air and water.

1464.text: And once again, disaster for some becomes a time of abundance for others.

1484.text: For the caimans, the small pools represent a veritable feast.

1487.text: The piranhas crowd together in muddy waters, where the lack of oxygen makes them deathly slow.

1493.text: So, to catch them all you need do is dive down into the water and swallow them down one by one.

1519.text: Our tortoise is now travelling across dry ground which until just a few days ago lay beneath the water.

1525.text: It is fifty degrees centigrade, and her dark shell rapidly absorbs the heat,

1531.text: while the dust from the dried-out mud chokes her.

1534.text: This is the plains at their most cruel.

1537.text: At least she is lucky in that she doesn't depend on the water as much as the fish,

1543.text: or on body temperature as much as the mammals,

1545.text: otherwise she too would be dead by now.

1557.text: Exhausted but persevering, the morrocoy reaches the shore of another pool,

1562.text: this one on such low-lying land that it will retain some water right through until the rains come.

1573.text: A group of leafy trees rises above the water at some distance and, thinking this is the forest,

1578.text: she enters the cool water which cools down her burning shell, bringing relief from the heat.

1590.text: But what the tortoise does not know is that what she thinks is the forest is in fact a group of trees in the water,

1596.text: a place chosen by the American ibises to establish their breeding colony.

1607.text: These jabiru storks, or wood ibises, always live close to the water.

1611.text: For them, this is the time to make the nests and bring their young into the world.

1617.text: The pools shrink and the fish are concentrated, so there is plenty of food and it is easy to catch.

1624.text: The ideal time to ensure the chicks get enough to eat.

1637.text: In years when food is abundant, the storks can raise up to five chicks,

1642.text: though three is the normal number.

1644.text: Feeding these voracious young is a never-ending job, which both parents share.

1650.text: But survival is not just a question of food.

1664.text: Living directly above a pool presents certain dangers.

1668.text: The chicks know no other world but the leaves and branches, and must stay here,

1674.text: close by the nest, until they develop feathers, their wings gain strength, and they are able to fly away.

1682.text: Until then, their lives will depend on prudence.

1686.text: Beneath the breeding colony lies death.

1705.text: The apparently peaceful waters hide sharp teeth beneath the green blanket of the water hyacinths.

1717.text: They are a silent, invisible army with powerful weapons,

1721.text: patiently waiting to gain revenge on the beings that pursue and devour them on the surface.

1733.text: The very name inspires respect among the local people:

1737.text: piranhas, fish armed with powerful jaws and razor-sharp teeth,

1741.text: shadows among the maze of roots, impatient to receive prey coming from above.

1755.text: If it loses its balance for just a second, the chick will fall to its death.

1760.text: The army swiftly moves into action, with incredible ferocity,

1764.text: reducing the victim to bones in just a minute or two.

1767.text: And then, in seconds, calm is restored the false calm of lurking death.

1785.text: Immobile among the hyacinths, our heroine has discovered that this is not her jungle home,

1789.text: but rather a patch of forest floating on water which bites.

1800.text: She decides to return to the shore as quickly as possible.

1807.text: Luckily, she is not wounded, nor does she give out smells that would attract the piranhas,

1811.text: and so, moving slowly, she remains unnoticed in the cloudy waters of the pool.

1816.text: But, at the surface, close to the shore she is heading for, other eyes are on the lookout.

1822.text: The tortoise is unaware of the presence of the caiman lurking among the hyacinths.

1827.text: Hidden and immobile, only his eyes emerge from the water, like periscopes, fixed on the nearby prey.

1834.text: The tortoise continues to swim, and then, just a few metres away, the predator attacks.

1848.text: An exhausted capybara has fallen into the jaws of the caiman.

1857.text: On the plains, weakness means death.

1860.text: But, the tragic end of the capybara has left the way clear for the frightened morrocoy.

1867.text: Again on dry land, she continues on her way, dreaming of the peace of her lost paradise.

1879.text: Since the men took her from her jungle home, many times she has witnessed violence and death.

1887.text: And, though she doesn't know it, the greatest dangers lie ahead.

1903.text: A growing commotion shatters the burning silence.

1910.text: The plains are divided into large cattle-breeding estates, and thousands of head of emaciated cattle daily roam across the parched grassland.

1925.text: For the tortoise, the cattle present no danger, thanks to the protection of her shell.

1930.text: But, among the forest of legs, she spots the cause of her misfortune, an enemy she has now learnt to avoid.

1937.text: So, camouflaged among the cattle, she remains immobile until the men pass by.

1954.text: The plains-dwellers move off without spotting her.

1956.text: Their only concern now is to round up the cattle and take them to the nearest ranch.

1960.text: Just like the wild animals, the domesticated cattle are more vulnerable in the dry season.

1969.text: and the cattle-breeders carry out exhaustive vaccination campaigns to prevent epidemics.

1992.text: For the vets it is a race against the clock.

1995.text: The cattle are threatened by numerous diseases:

2003.text: a trypanosomiasis which attacks equine populations.

2007.text: The cattle can infect wild animals such as the capybaras.

2012.text: And hundreds of thousands of zebus and horses roam free across the dry plain, endangering the ecological stability of the entire system.

2040.text: The tortoise continues on her way.

2042.text: She has overcome the dangers of the water, the threat of the caiman,

2046.text: a close brush with man, and the torture of the sun.

2050.text: And now, for the first time on the worst day in her life,

2053.text: a light breeze blows across the plain, announcing sunset.

2068.text: The scavengers have had a busy day.

2071.text: But our tortoise has survived, and now, as the sun goes down, she regains her strength.

2076.text: She will not rest during the night, but will take advantage of the shadows and the cool

2099.text: At dusk, the plains again come to life.

2102.text: Now that the suffocating heat has passed, the animals renew their activities, as the inferno declares a temporary truce.

2109.text: And the plains shimmer and glow, showing a different face,

2114.text: rewarding the survivors with this incredible beauty.

2127.text: Sunset marks the change between two worlds.

2139.text: Grasslands, pools and jungle are transformed in the light of the moon.

2143.text: New creatures come out with the night, creatures that never see the sun,

2148.text: the least well-known inhabitants of the plains.

2159.text: In the jungle, the moon guides the way for some old friends of ours.

2177.text: again in search of the treasure that has fallen from the trees during the day.

2216.text: and though there is just the slightest breeze, thanks to their keen sense of smell, the boars have detected the feline,

2281.text: Or, like this turtle, laying their eggs in a hole,

2646.text: An unsuspecting iguana rests among the lower branches of a young monkey-pod tree.

2651.text: Its natural camouflage hides it among the intense green vegetation

2655.text: but, believing it is safe, it is not sufficiently cautious in its movements,

2660.text: and is immediately spotted by vigilant eyes.

2663.text: The ocelot doesn't yet know what animal it is, but the iguana's movements have alerted him to the fact that there is something alive here,

2672.text: and for any feline in the forest something alive means something to eat.

2683.text: Finally, the ocelot emerges from the jungle, and the iguana sees him.

2687.text: Immediately, the reptile freezes. It knows that immobility will be its only chance against such an agile enemy.

2694.text: But this strategy has been employed too late.

2715.text: Now, he knows what it is and where it is.

2718.text: And the iguana's fate has been decided.

2741.text: Though they are small in size, these patches of jungle on the plains are home to large hunters.

2746.text: The cats are the most efficient of all, and in the forests there are five different species.

2751.text: Outside, on the grasslands, they have been virtually exterminated by man, who considers them a threat to the cattle,

2758.text: but here, hidden in the dense foliage,

2761.text: they survive thanks to the abundance of prey and the green wall that keeps men out.

2782.text: After an unsuccessful night's hunting, the jaguar is hungry.

2798.text: He rarely hunts during the day

2800.text: fear of humans has turned him into a nocturnal predator.

2803.text: But since the peccaries managed to escape the previous night,

2807.text: he has not eaten, and his hunger is now urgent.

2820.text: Unfortunately for him, the howler monkeys have seen him, and raised the alarm.

2825.text: Now, the entire forest, knowing he is prowling around, is on the alert.

2834.text: He is not the only hunter searching for prey in the forest.

2838.text: At the other end of the little jungle another creature of the night lurks among the vegetation.

2850.text: Almost all the black jaguars have fallen victim to the bullets of the fur hunters.

2855.text: But their colouring, fatal out in the open, protects them in the darkness of the jungle.

2864.text: The vigilant howlers don't take their eyes off him, and scream out the threat of his presence.

2868.text: But a dozing iguana has not heard them.

2872.text: He is warming up beneath the first rays of sunlight,

2876.text: and only when the jaguar is virtually on him does he seem to realise just how close death is.

2889.text: It was a close shave, but the reptiles ability to dive has saved its life.

2895.text: The jungle offers as many opportunities to catch a prey like this

2900.text: as for these to escape from their hunters, and so the ecological balance is preserved.

2913.text: Finally, the longed-for jungle lies before her.

2916.text: Hungry and tired, exhausted after crossing the inferno,

2920.text: our tortoise finally reaches her personal paradise.

2924.text: The jungle hides dangers, but ones she is aware of and knows how to avoid.

2931.text: It is her home, the place she is adapted to, and after her many trials,

2938.text: she victoriously enters the shady undergrowth,

2940.text: the final goal of his risky adventure.

2951.text: And there to welcome her, shortly after entering the green canopy of the trees,

2956.text: the morrocoy tortoise finds tasty flowers which restore her strength.

2966.text: And this is not the only pleasant surprise.

2970.text: Another morrocoy tortoise has seen her arrive,

2973.text: and approaches, to check out this intruder who has wandered into his territory.

2983.text: The saddle-like shape of its shell tells us it is an adult male.

2987.text: And our travelling tortoise is a female, so there are no problems of territoriality.

2999.text: The nightmare is over. For her, the jungle means returning to life.

3005.text: She is back in her natural surroundings, the world into which she was born, and now the future is promising.

3013.text: She has shelter, food, and even a mate.

3017.text: But she will not easily forget her journey across the open plains.

3022.text: After all, not everyone ventures into hell and lives to tell the tale.
